questions.text:
Arrange lung hilar structures from anterior to posterior:

 

1. Primary bronchus

2. Bronchial artery

3. Pulmonary vein

4. Pulmonary artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3, 4, 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Lung hilar structures are arranged from the anterior to posterior in the order:

 

  • Pulmonary vein
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Primary bronchus
  • Bronchial artery

 

The superior vena cava and right atrium are seen in front of the right root and terminal part of the azygos vein superiorly. The hilar structures are arranged from the superior to inferior as:

 

  • Superior lobar bronchus
  • Pulmonary artery
  • Principal bronchus
  • Inferior pulmonary vein

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The structure passing through the central tendon of the diaphragm is: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior vena cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. The IVC passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening, which is situated to the right of the central tendon. This opening allows the IVC to move between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophagus: The esophagus passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the esophageal hiatus, which is located just to the left of the central tendon. This allows the esophagus to traverse from the thoracic cavity to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option B. Aorta: The descending (thoracic) aorta carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body. It passes through the diaphragm via the aortic hiatus, which is posterior to the central tendon. The aorta then continues its descent into the abdominal cavity.

 

Option D. Sympathetic Chain: The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, consists of a series of ganglia connected by nerve fibers. It runs vertically along each side of the vertebral column and is not directly associated with the diaphragm or its central tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diaphragm has three anatomic openings: the aortic hiatus (T12), the esophageal hiatus (T10), and the caval foramen (T8)

 

  • The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm from the caval foramen.
  • Esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus.
  • Aorta passes through the aortic hiatus.

 

Sympathetic chain passes through the minor apertures crossing the crura of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Where are the Ito cells in the liver located? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Space of disse

 

In the Disse space are Ito cells/Hepatic stellate cells. Their origins are mesenchymal.

 

Between the liver sinusoid and the hepatocytes is a region known as the space of Disse, sometimes known as the perisinusoidal space.

 

Significance of Ito cells:

 

Most of the time, ito cells (also known as stellate cells) are dormant. They are a substantial source of growth factors essential for liver homeostasis and regeneration and store the fat-soluble vitamin A in their lipid droplets.

 

Ito cells become active when there is liver damage. They release intralobular matrix components such collagen type III (reticular) fibres and replace injured hepatocytes with collagenous scar tissue. This leads to hepatic fibrosis.

 

Note: A narrow space which separates limiting plate (a sleeve of modified hepatocytes) from the connective tissue of the portal area is known as space of moll.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Space of Moll:

 

  • The Space of Moll is located in the eyelid and is not related to the liver. Specifically, it refers to a part of the eyelid's lymphatic drainage system.
  • It has no relevance to the location of Ito cells.

 

Option C. Sinusoids:

 

  • Sinusoids are the capillary-like vessels in the liver where the exchange of substances occurs between the blood and hepatocytes.
  • While Ito cells are closely related to sinusoids and are found in the perisinusoidal space, they are not located within the sinusoids themselves.

 

Option D. Bile Canaliculi:

 

  • Bile canaliculi are small ducts between hepatocytes that collect bile produced by the hepatocytes.
  • Ito cells are not located in the bile canaliculi. Instead, these canaliculi are lined by hepatocytes that actively secrete bile into them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Space of Disse (perisinusoidal space) is a small space between the sinusoidal endothelial cells and the hepatocytes. Ito cells are located in this space. When there is liver injury, these cells can become activated, transform into myofibroblast-like cells, and contribute to the production of collagen and extracellular matrix, leading to liver fibrosis.

questions.text: At what time during intrauterine life does the talus ossification center appear? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 months

 

Explanation:

 

According to the 42nd edition of Gray's Anatomy, the correct answer is 6 months.

The talus is the uppermost bone of the foot, articulating with the tibia and fibula above and the calcaneus below. The head of the talus articulates with the navicular bone, which is a boat-shaped bone important for the passage of the dorsalis pedis artery. The navicular bone articulates with the three cuneiforms (medial, intermediate, and lateral) and the first three metatarsals. These bones, along with the medial half of the calcaneus, participate in the medial longitudinal arch of the foot.

 

The 4th and 5th metatarsals, the cuboid bone, and the lateral half of the calcaneus contribute to the lateral longitudinal arch. It is important to note that the phalanges do not participate in the arches of the foot, as demonstrated by the case of New Zealand cricketer Martin Guptill, who had some of his toes amputated without affecting his running and jumping abilities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secondary Ossification centers already present when an infant is born includes -

 

  • Distal femur and Proximal tibia - 7 weeks
  • Humerus - 8 weeks
  • Calcaneus - 3-4th months.
  • Talus – 6th months
  • Cuboid – 9th months

questions.text: Identify the structure which is responsible for elevation and is supplied by the nerve emergency from the structure shown in the image? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Risorius

 

Explanation:

 

Risorius is supplied by the facial nerve, resulting in the marked elevation. The image depicts the floor of the fourth ventricle, as well as the facial colliculus.

 

 

The facial colliculus is a raised area on the floor of the fourth ventricle in the brainstem, and it is associated with the motor nucleus of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). The facial nerve is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression, including the risorius muscle, which is one of the muscles that can cause elevation of the corner of the mouth in smiling. Therefore, the structure that is supplied by the nerve causing this elevation would be the risorius muscle.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral rectus: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the lateral part of the common tendinous ring. It is innervated by the abducens nerve.

 

Option B. Superior oblique: Is an extraocular muscle that arises from the body of the sphenoid. It is innervated by the trochlear nerve.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle is supplied by the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III). This muscle is responsible for raising the upper eyelid (levator means "elevator"), allowing you to open your eyes.

 

The oculomotor nerve also innervates several other muscles that control eye movement and pupil constriction, making it an important cranial nerve for eye function

 

Educational Objective:

 

The risorius muscle, responsible for pulling the corner of the mouth laterally and aiding in expressions like smiling, is innervated by the facial nerve.

choices.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava
Right and left lobe of liver

questions.text: The cholecysto-vena caval line is an anatomical landmark that connects which of the following structures? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gallbladder and inferior vena cava

 

  • The cholecysto-vena caval line (Cantlie line) considered as true mid line of liver.
  • The Cantlie line is a fictitious line that divides the liver into two parts.
  • It contains the middle hepatic vein and extends from the midpoint of the gallbladder fossa at the inferior margin of the liver to the midpoint of the groove for inferior vena cava (IC).

 

 

Anatomy on visceral surface of the liver with division into right and left lobes by the plane of Rex-Cantlie line.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Porta Hepatis and Inferior Vena Cava: The porta hepatis, often called the "hilum of the liver," is a deep fissure on the inferior surface of the liver where several key structures, including the portal vein, common hepatic duct, and hepatic artery, enter or leave the liver. Though the porta hepatis is an essential landmark in liver anatomy and surgery, it's not associated with the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option C. Caudate Lobe and Quadrangular Lobe: There isn't a distinct "quadrangular lobe" in the human liver. The liver has main lobes named right, left, caudate, and quadrate lobes. The caudate and quadrate lobes are smaller lobes situated on the liver's inferior surface. While they have importance in liver anatomy, they don't define the cholecysto-vena caval line.

 

Option D. Right and Left Lobe of Liver: On the Diaphragamatic surface Tthe human liver is typically divided into a larger right lobe and a smaller left lobe by the falciform ligament (anteriorly). The cholecysto-vena caval line helps delineate the boundary between the right and left lobes when viewed posteriorly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn from the fundus of the gallbladder to the point where the inferior vena cava (IVC) pierces the diaphragm. It roughly demarcates the boundary between the right and left lobes of the liver, especially when viewed from behind (posterior view).

questions.text: A patient presented with jaw swelling and weight loss. Suspecting a malignancy, the submandibular gland was resected. Which is the most likely nerve to be damaged during submandibular gland resection?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lingual nerve

 

Lingual Nerve: This is the branch of mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It runs close to the submandibular gland and is therefore at risk during submandibular gland surgery.

 

Sensory Distribution: Provides general sensory (pain, temperature, touch) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. (Note: Taste sensation for this region is carried by the chorda tympani nerve, which joins the lingual nerve for a short course.)

 

Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of general sensation to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.

 

 

Injury:

 

Because dissection of the submandibular duct from the nerve is required during submandibular gland resection, the lingual nerve is at risk of injury. It is also linked to the submandibular ganglion, which will expose the nerve within the operating field.

 

The symptoms of lingual nerve injury differ depending on whether the lesion is proximal or distal to the point where it is joined by the chorda tympani nerve.

 

  • Proximal injury: There is loss of sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, gingivae, oral mucosa, lower lip, and chin.
  • Distal injury: In addition to features of proximal injury, secretion from the salivary glands below the oral fissure and taste from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue is also lost.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nerve to Mylohyoid: This nerve is a branch of the inferior alveolar nerve (which is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3). It descends on the medial surface of the mandible in the mylohyoid groove.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies the mylohyoid muscle and the anterior belly of the digastric muscle.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in the elevation of the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth during swallowing and speech.

 

Option B. Inferior Alveolar Nerve: It's a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, V3. It enters the mandibular foramen and runs through the mandibular canal.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Does not directly supply any muscles.
  • Sensory Distribution: Provides sensation to the mandibular teeth, lower lip, and chin.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Option D. Hypoglossal Nerve (12th Cranial Nerve): This cranial nerve exits the skull via the hypoglossal canal and supplies the muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Muscles Innervated: Supplies almost all the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus (which is innervated by the vagus nerve).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Tongue deviation to the side of the lesion due to weakened tongue muscles on that side. If you asked the patient to protrude their tongue, it would point towards the side of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented with symptoms of inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits. He was also not able to hold a piece of paper between his fingers. What is the likely site of injury?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. C

 

Explanation:

 

An ulnar nerve damage is suggested by the clinical scenario, which includes a positive card test and the inability to flex the distal interphalangeal joint of the 4th and 5th digits.

 

The most likely site of injury would thus be medial epicondyle: site C

 

 

Damage to the ulnar nerve at the medial epicondyle causes paralysis of the flexor carpi ulnaris (lack of ulnar deviation) and the medial half of the flexor digitorum profundus (loss of distal interphalangeal joint flexion). Hypothenar paralysis (which causes atrophy) and sensory loss are the results. Moreover, the extensor digitorum and flexor digitorum superficialis (provided by the radial nerve and median nerve, respectively) continue to function. The third and fourth digits are therefore not completely paralysed. The palmar interossei's fragility, which causes a loss of adduction, is what causes the positive card test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Head of the Humerus: Articulates with the shoulder joint. Injury here typically affects shoulder movement, not the distal functions like finger flexion or sensory issues associated with the ulnar nerve.

 

Option B. Intertubercular Groove: Houses the tendon of the biceps brachii. Mainly affects movements related to the biceps muscle, not ulnar nerve functions.

 

Option D. Lateral Epicondyle: Attachment site for forearm extensor muscles. Primarily involved in conditions like lateral epicondylitis, which causes localized pain rather than the broader sensory and motor deficits seen in ulnar nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ulnar nerve branches and supply:

 

 

Superficial branch supplies palmaris brevis, skin on the palmar surface of medial 1½ fingers. The deep branch runs within the concavity of deep palmar arch and supplies all intrinsic muscles of the hand (except first 2 lumbricals and thenar muscles).

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supply which of the following structure?

 

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Ans.  A. 1, 2, 3 & 4

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk and arises from the subclavian artery. It runs upward in front of the vertebral column and enters the thyroid gland at its lower pole. Along its course, the inferior thyroid artery gives off several branches that supply the thyroid gland, parathyroid glands, larynx, trachea, esophagus, and the pharynx.

 

  1. Thyroid: The inferior thyroid artery primarily supplies blood to the thyroid gland. The gland requires a substantial blood supply due to its high metabolic activity, especially when it's actively producing thyroid hormones. The inferior thyroid artery enters the thyroid gland at its posterior aspect and supplies the majority of the gland, especially its inferior portion.
  2. Parathyroid: The parathyroid glands are small endocrine glands located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland. There are usually four parathyroid glands: two superior and two inferior. The inferior parathyroid glands are typically supplied by the inferior thyroid artery. The blood supply to these glands is crucial because they produce parathyroid hormone (PTH), which plays a vital role in calcium homeostasis.
  3. Esophagus: The esophagus, especially its cervical portion, may receive some blood supply from the branches of the inferior thyroid artery. However, it's essential to note that the primary blood supply to the esophagus comes from the esophageal branches of various arteries along its length, such as the aorta and the left gastric artery.
  4. Thymus: While the inferior thyroid artery is not a primary source of blood supply for the thymus, there can be some anastomotic connections between the vessels supplying these structures in the anterior mediastinum. However, the primary blood supply to the thymus comes from the internal thoracic and anterior mediastinal branches.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyroid gland receives its main arterial blood supply from the superior and inferior thyroid arteries. The inferior thyroid artery also supplies the parathyroid glands with blood. Additionally, its branches provide blood to the esophagus, larynx, trachea, thymus and pharynx.

 

Branches:

 

  • Pharyngeal branches
  • Ascending cervical artery
  • Inferior artery
  • Muscular branches

 

Thymic branches – originate from internal thoracic, inferior thyroid arteryand often superior thyroid arteries & supply the thymus.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with an arrow: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pulmonary trunk

 

The given image represents a cross-sectional view of the thorax, and the structure marked by the arrow is identified as the pulmonary trunk. The key points to identify the pulmonary trunk are its location and the surrounding structures in the thoracic cross-section.

 

  • Pulmonary Trunk: The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel that arises from the right ventricle of the heart and bifurcates into the right and left pulmonary arteries. It is situated anterior to the aorta and is clearly visible in the image as a large tube dividing into two branches.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carina: The carina is the point at which the trachea bifurcates into the left and right main bronchi. It is located lower in the thoracic cavity and is not associated with the structures visible in the image.

 

Option B. Superior vena cava: The superior vena cava is located to the right of the sternum and is not the structure marked by the arrow.

 

Option D. Arch of Aorta: The arch of the aorta is the curved portion of the aorta that gives rise to the brachiocephalic trunk, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery. In a cross-sectional view, it appears as an elongated structure, not as the large round structure marked by the arrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pulmonary trunk is a major vessel located anterior to the aorta, bifurcating into the right and left pulmonary arteries, and is the structure identified by the arrow in the cross-sectional image of the thorax.

questions.text: A 39-year-old patient presents to the OPD with the complaint of pain over his ear. He also complains of difficulty in eating food and the inability to close his eyes completely. On examination, there is a swelling below his ear. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved in this condition? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Facial nerve

 

Explanation:

 

The patient's symptoms, including ear pain, difficulty eating, and inability to close the eye completely, strongly suggest a case of facial palsy or Bell's palsy. Bell's palsy is a condition characterized by sudden weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, typically affecting one side of the face. The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, and its dysfunction leads to the presented symptoms.

 

The presence of a swelling below the ear further supports the involvement of the facial nerve. The parotid gland, located in this region, is closely associated with the facial nerve, which divides into five terminal branches within the gland. Damage or inflammation of the parotid gland can lead to compression or involvement of the facial nerve, resulting in facial palsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Great auricular nerve: Incorrect. While the great auricular nerve provides sensory innervation over the angle of the mandible and the area around the ear (shaving area), it is not directly responsible for the motor functions affected in this case. If the patient had ear pain or loss of sensation in the shaving area without the Bell's palsy features, the great auricular nerve could have been considered.

 

Option C. Vagus nerve: Incorrect. The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) does not directly control the facial muscles or cause the symptoms described here.

 

Option D. Auriculotemporal nerve: Incorrect. The auriculotemporal nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, supplies sensory innervation to the auricle and temporal region but does not control the facial muscles or cause the symptoms of facial palsy. If the patient had symptoms like increased sweating, redness, or blood supply in this area, it could have suggested an auriculotemporal nerve syndrome (Frey's syndrome).

 

Educational Objective:

 

The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for controlling the muscles of facial expression, and its dysfunction can lead to facial palsy or Bell's palsy, characterized by weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles, difficulty eating, and inability to close the eye completely.

questions.text: A defect in which of the following aortic arches causes the defect shown in the image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 6th left

 

The image depicts a patent ductus arteriosus due to a defect in the left side of the 6th pharyngeal arch.

 

Normally, the ductus arteriosus closes within 72 hours of birth. However, in cases of PDA, the ductus arteriosus fails to close, leading to abnormal blood flow between the two major arteries.

 

Presentation - Hyperdynamic precordium, bounding peripheral pulses, wide pulse pressure, a machine-like continuous or systolic murmur, cardiomegaly, increased pulmonary vascular markings, hepatomegaly, increasing oxygen dependence, carbon dioxide retention, and renal failure.

 

Treatment options for PDA include medication, minimally invasive catheter-based procedures, and surgical closure. Medications like indomethacin or ibuprofen can be given to encourage closure of the ductus arteriosus.

 

The aortic arch arteries, also referred to as the branchial or pharyngeal arch arteries, are a series of six paired arterial structures that arise from the aortic sac during embryonic development. They play a crucial role in the formation of the major arteries of the head, neck, and thorax. Abnormal development or persistence of these arteries can lead to a range of congenital anomalies.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. 4th left and Option B. 4th right: These arches are primarily involved in forming parts of the aorta and its major branches, not directly related to the defect depicted in the image.

 

Option D. 6th right: While the right 6th arch also contributes to the development of the pulmonary artery system, its defects are usually not associated with PDA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Here's a list of defects related to the aortic arch arteries:

 

  1. Double Aortic Arch: This involves the persistence of both the right and left fourth aortic arches. It can form a vascular ring around the trachea and esophagus, which can cause respiratory and feeding difficulties.
  2. Right Aortic Arch: This results from the regression of the left fourth aortic arch. Depending on the persistence of the ductus arteriosus, different types can form, some of which can lead to a vascular ring.
  3. Interrupted Aortic Arch: Here, there's a complete loss of continuity between the ascending and descending parts of the aorta. It's often associated with other congenital heart defects.
  4. Persistent Truncus Arteriosus: This is a failure of the truncus arteriosus to divide into the pulmonary trunk and aorta, leading to a single arterial trunk emerging from the heart supplying both systemic, pulmonary, and coronary circulations.
  5. Coarctation of the Aorta: It's a narrowing of the aorta, often occurring near the site of the ductus arteriosus. It can lead to high blood pressure in the upper body and arms and lower blood pressure in the lower body and legs.
  6. Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA): After birth, the ductus arteriosus normally closes, but in this condition, it remains open, leading to abnormal blood flow between the aorta and pulmonary artery.
  7. Aberrant Right Subclavian Artery: This is a variant in the branching pattern where the right subclavian artery arises as the last branch of the aortic arch and can course posterior to the esophagus.
  8. Cervical Aortic Arch: Here, the aortic arch is positioned higher than normal in the neck. It is usually of no clinical significance but can be identified radiologically.
  9. Aortopulmonary Septal Defects: These defects involve abnormal connections between the aorta and the pulmonary trunk.
  10. Vascular Rings: These are congenital anomalies of the aortic arch and its branches that encircle and compress the trachea and esophagus.

questions.text: Fibers from the structure marked in blue, terminate at which of the following? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Red nucleus

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle is the peduncle that is highlighted in the picture. Deep cerebellar nuclei that extend to the brainstem, red nucleus, and thalamus are connected by fibres to the superior cerebellar peduncle. The fibres of the ventral spinocerebellar tract are also present.

 

 

 

All of the efferent fibres from the dentate, emboliform, and globose nuclei Majority of efferents from the fastigial nucleus pass via inferior cerebellar peduncle though few may pass via superior peduncle. The caudal mesencephalon is where its fibres decussate, and they are intended to synapse in the thalamus and opposite red nucleus. Only afferent fibres from the contralateral pontine nuclei are present in the middle cerebellar peduncle. Afferent and efferent fibres that travel to the vestibular nuclei are both present in the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

 

The image below summarizes the various tracts in the cerebellar unit.

 

 

  • It has two surfaces - superior and inferior separated by a horizontal fissure. It is connected to the other parts of the central nervous system via three peduncles
    • Superior cerebellar peduncle -connecting to the midbrain
    • Middle cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the pons
    • Inferior cerebellar peduncle - connecting to the medulla oblongata

 

The superior cerebellar peduncle, also known as the brachium conjunctivum, is a major white matter tract connecting the cerebellum to the midbrain. Its fibers originate in the cerebellum, ascend, and decussate (cross over) at the level of the midbrain to end primarily in the contralateral red nucleus and the thalamus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fastigial nucleus: The fastigial nucleus is one of the four deep cerebellar nuclei (others being the globose, emboliform, and dentate nuclei). While the fastigial nucleus does send fibers out of the cerebellum, it primarily connects through the inferior cerebellar peduncle to the vestibular nuclei and the reticular formation, not the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option B. Inferior olivary nucleus: The inferior olivary nucleus is located in the medulla oblongata and is involved in motor learning and coordination. It primarily sends fibers to the cerebellum through the inferior cerebellar peduncle, and it receives cerebellar feedback, but not directly from the superior cerebellar peduncle.

 

Option D. Subthalamus: The subthalamus is part of the diencephalon and is closely related to the basal ganglia circuitry, particularly in the indirect pathway. While the subthalamus does receive some cerebellar input, the primary connection from the superior cerebellar peduncle is to the red nucleus and not directly to the subthalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The red nucleus is located in the midbrain and plays a role in motor coordination. Fibers from the cerebellum via the superior cerebellar peduncle decussate and terminate primarily in the contralateral red nucleus. From the red nucleus, some of these fibers continue on to the thalamus. Thus, the red nucleus is a major target of the superior cerebellar peduncle fibers.

questions.text: Calcium deposition is seen in which layer? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) D

 

Calcium deposition occurs primarily in the zone of calcified cartilage, which is represented by option D in the image. This zone is located near the metaphysis of a growing bone, where cartilage is being replaced by bone tissue. The calcification process involves the accumulation of calcium salts in the cartilage matrix, leading to its hardening and subsequent replacement by bone. This is a crucial step in the endochondral ossification process, which allows for the longitudinal growth of bones.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: This layer represents the reserve zone, where chondrocytes are relatively inactive and not yet undergoing proliferation or hypertrophy. Calcium deposition does not occur in this zone.

 

Option B: This layer is the proliferative zone, where chondrocytes are rapidly dividing. While important for bone growth, this zone does not involve calcium deposition.

 

Option C: This is the hypertrophic zone, where chondrocytes increase in size and prepare for calcification. Although it is a precursor to the calcification process, actual calcium deposition occurs in the next zone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zone of calcified cartilage is where calcium deposition occurs, leading to the hardening of cartilage and its eventual replacement by bone during the growth of long bones.

questions.text: Medial lemniscus is a continuation of which of the following structures? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fasciculus gracilis

 

Medial lemniscus is a continuation of fasciculus gracilis as well as fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Posterior column-medial lemniscal pathway:

 

In the dorsal horn, first-order axons carrying proprioception vibration  and two point discrimination sensations continue their upward journey as the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Fibers of these fasciculi synapse on the second-order neurons of the ipsilateral nuclei gracilis and cuneatus in the medulla oblongata, respectively.

 

Axons of these second-order neurons then cross over as the internal arcuate fibers to form the medial lemniscus in the contralateral medulla.

 

These second-order axons ascend through the brainstem to reach the third-order neuronal cell bodies in the ventral posterior lateral nucleus of the thalamus. Axons from the third-order neurons then project through the posterior limb of the internal capsule to reach the primary somatosensory cortex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinothalamic tract: The spinothalamic tract is an important ascending pathway that primarily carries pain, temperature, and crude touch sensations. The pathway originates from the spinal cord and projects directly to the thalamus without becoming the medial lemniscus. However, after relaying in the thalamus, fibers from the spinothalamic tract and the medial lemniscus converge to project to similar regions of the cerebral cortex.

 

Option B. Spinocerebellar tract: The spinocerebellar tracts (anterior and posterior) are pathways that convey proprioceptive information (concerning the position and movement of body parts) from the body to the cerebellum. They do not form the medial lemniscus.

 

Option C. Spinotectal tract: The spinotectal tract is an ascending pathway that carries sensory information related to reflex movements of the eyes and head in response to visual and tactile stimuli. It connects the spinal cord to the tectum of the midbrain (specifically, the superior colliculus). It does not become the medial lemniscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fasciculus gracilis (and its counterpart, the fasciculus cuneatus) are ascending tracts in the spinal cord that carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioceptive sensations from the body to the brain.

 

These fibers travel upwards in the spinal cord and synapse in the nucleus gracilis (and nucleus cuneatus for the fasciculus cuneatus) located in the medulla oblongata. After synapsing, second-order neurons cross the midline and form the medial lemniscus, which then ascends to the thalamus.

 

Thus, the medial lemniscus is indeed a continuation of the fibers originally present in the fasciculus gracilis (and fasciculus cuneatus).

questions.text: The pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia encloses all of the following except?(INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternocleidomastoid

 

All the above structures are enclosed by the pretracheal layer of deep cervical fascia except sternocleidomastoid. It is enclosed by the investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

 

The deep cervical fascia of the neck is organized into the following layers:

 

  • The investing layer - surrounds all structures in the neck
  • The prevertebral layer - surrounds the vertebral column and the deep muscles associated with the back.
  • The pretracheal layer - encloses the viscera of the neck
  • The carotid sheath - receives a contribution from the other three fascial layers

 

The strap muscles of the neck, including the sternohyoid, omohyoid, sternothyroid, and thyrohyoid, are covered by the pretracheal fascia. To encapsulate the thyroid gland, it divides. The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which is located in the groove between the trachea and the oesophagus, is likewise surrounded by this tissue.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Esophagus: The esophagus is indeed enclosed by the pretracheal fascia in its cervical portion. The fascia extends posteriorly from the trachea to envelop the esophagus, giving some form of fascial support to this structure as it descends through the neck.

 

Option C. Sternohyoid: The sternohyoid muscle is one of the infrahyoid muscles and lies superficially in the anterior part of the neck. It is indeed enclosed by the pretracheal layer of the deep cervical fascia. This layer of fascia extends inferiorly from the hyoid bone to the thorax and surrounds the thyroid gland, trachea, and infrahyoid muscles, including the sternohyoid.

 

Option D. Thyroid gland: The thyroid gland is an endocrine gland situated anteriorly in the midline and the side of the neck, straddling the trachea. The pretracheal fascia contributes to the formation of the capsule of the thyroid gland, thus enclosing it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM) is not enclosed by the pretracheal fascia. Instead, the SCM is associated with the superficial layer of the deep cervical fascia (also known as the investing layer). This layer of the fascia envelops both the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, acting as an investing layer for these superficial neck muscles.

questions.text: In the intervertebral disc shown in the image, which structure gives rise to the annulus fibrosus? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Mark d (Sclerotome)

 

Explanation:

 

  • The annulus fibrosus is derived from the sclerotome portion of the somites (mesoderm)
  • The sclerotome cells migrate to surround the notochord and form the fibrous outer ring of the intervertebral disc
  • This mesenchymal tissue differentiates into the fibrocartilaginous structure of the annulus fibrosus

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mark b (Notochord):

 

  • While the notochord gives rise to the nucleus pulposus (central portion), it does not form the annulus fibrosus
  • The notochord degenerates everywhere except within the intervertebral discs where it forms the nucleus pulposus

 

Option C. Mark a (Neural crest):

 

  • Neural crest cells contribute to various structures including melanocytes, peripheral nervous system, and facial bones
  • They do not participate in the formation of the intervertebral disc components

 

Option D. Mark c (Surface ectoderm):

 

  • Surface ectoderm gives rise to epidermis and its derivatives
  • It has no role in the development of deep structures like intervertebral discs

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understanding the embryological origins of intervertebral disc components:

 

 

  • Nucleus pulposus ← Notochord
  • Annulus fibrosus ← Sclerotome (mesoderm)
  • Cartilaginous endplates ← Sclerotome
  • This knowledge is crucial for understanding disc pathologies and their developmental basis

questions.text: Which structure forms the lateral boundary of the Hasselbach’s triangle? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior epigastric vessels

 

Explanation:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle is an important anatomical region related to the anterior abdominal wall and is relevant to the understanding of inguinal hernias.

 

The Hasselbalch triangle's boundaries are formed by the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, the rectus abdominis muscle medially, and the inguinal ligament forming the base.

 

This triangle is discussed in the context of inguinal hernias, where a direct inguinal hernia occurs when the hernia protrudes through the Hasselbalch triangle, while an indirect inguinal hernia occurs outside of this triangle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral vessels: The femoral vessels are not mentioned as forming the lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle.

 

Option C. Inguinal ligament: The inguinal ligament forms the base of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Option D. Rectus abdominis: The rectus abdominis muscle forms the medial boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, not the lateral boundary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral boundary of the Hasselbalch triangle, an important anatomical region related to inguinal hernias, is formed by the inferior epigastric vessels.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The primary actions of the gluteus maximus are hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are important for movements like standing up from a sitting position, climbing stairs, and running.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abduction and external rotation: The gluteus maximus does contribute to abduction but not external rotation. The primary muscles responsible for hip external rotation are the deep muscles of the hip joint i.e., Piriformis, gemelli superior and inferior, quadratus femoris.

 

Option C. Extension, adduction, and lateral rotation: While extension and lateral rotation are correct, adduction is not a primary action of the gluteus maximus. Adduction is more associated with the adductor muscles of the thigh (muscles of medial compartment of thigh).
 

 

Option D. Flexion and abduction: Flexion and abduction are not the primary actions of the gluteus maximus. These movements are primarily associated with other muscles like the iliopsoas for hip flexion and the tensor fasciae latae for hip abduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus muscle, which is attached to the gluteal tuberosity of the femur, primarily performs hip extension and lateral rotation. These actions are essential for tasks such as standing up, climbing stairs, and running. Remember, despite contributing to abduction, the gluteus maximus does not support external rotation as a primary action.

questions.text: The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of which embryonic pharyngeal arch artery? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 6th arch

 

The long left recurrent laryngeal nerve is due to the persistence of the left 6th arch artery.

 

  • During embryonic development, the aortic arches give rise to several structures in the neck and chest.
  • The 6th arch artery, which is present on both the right and left sides, gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus.
  • As the arch arteries regress and are replaced by the adult structures, the recurrent laryngeal nerves, which innervate the muscles of the larynx, become trapped behind the great vessels.
  • The distal 6th arch artery vanishes on the right side. The right recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under the 4th arch artery, which becomes the future right subclavian artery, because there is no 5th arch artery.
  • On the left side, the 6th arch artery persists, which develops into ductus arteriosus, which later forms ligamentum arteriosum.
  • Due to the persistence of the 6th arch artery, the left recurrent laryngeal nerve is caught under it and therefore, has a relatively long course.
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the aortic arch on its way to the larynx.
  • In the case of the long left recurrent laryngeal nerve, the nerve passes inferior to the ligamentum arteriosum, which is a remnant of the ductus arteriosus that is derived from the 6th arch artery.
  •  This can lead to an increased risk of injury to the nerve during surgical procedures involving the thorax or neck.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3rd arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 3rd pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the common carotid arteries and the proximal part of the internal carotid arteries.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: It is not directly related to the course of the recurrent laryngeal nerve, and therefore, its persistence or anomalies don't affect the recurrent laryngeal nerve's course.

 

Option B. 4th arch:

 

  • Derivative: The 4th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the left side into the arch of the aorta and on the right side into the right subclavian artery.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve, which arises from the vagus nerve, initially descends and then ascends around the 4th arch artery. However, this is not responsible for the long course of the left recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Option C. 5th arch:

 

  • Derivative: Interestingly, in many cases, the 5th pharyngeal arch artery is rudimentary or even absent in humans. When present, it doesn't form any significant structures in the mature circulatory system.
  • Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: Given its rudimentary nature, the 5th arch artery doesn't have a defined relationship with the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The 6th pharyngeal arch artery contributes to the formation of the pulmonary arteries and the ductus arteriosus on the left side.

 

Relation to the recurrent laryngeal nerve: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve hooks under the ductus arteriosus (derived from the left 6th arch artery). In evolutionary terms, as the heart descended and the neck elongated during development, the nerve remained hooked around this artery, leading to its longer course on the left side. On the right side, the nerve hooks under the right subclavian artery (which isn't directly derived from the 6th arch but is related to its positioning). If there were a right-sided aortic arch (a rare congenital anomaly), the right recurrent laryngeal nerve would also have a longer course, similar to the left.

questions.text: Which of the following structures of the scapula is palpable in the infraclavicular fossa? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The part of the scapula marked as "A" in this image is palpable and it is the coracoid process.

 

The apex of the coracoid process lies approximately 2.5cm below the clavicle, immediately lateral to the infraclavicular fossa (deltopectoral triangle). Hence, the coracoid process can be palpated below the clavicle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. B- Acromion process - Located at the top of the shoulder, this process forms the highest point of the shoulder and serves as an attachment for the clavicle and muscles of the shoulder. It is not palpable in the infraclavicular fossa.

 

Option C. C- Glenoid fossa - This is the socket part of the scapula that articulates with the head of the humerus to form the shoulder joint. It is not palpable externally due to its deep location.

 

Option D. D- Infraspinous fossa - A broad surface on the posterior aspect of the scapula, covered largely by the infraspinatus muscle. It is not palpable from the anterior aspect of the body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The coracoid process (marked as A) is the scapular structure that can be palpated in the infraclavicular fossa, just below the clavicle. This palpation is useful for clinical assessments related to shoulder injuries and muscular attachments.

questions.text: Shape of Trapezius muscle is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Triangular

 

Explanation:

 

  • The trapezius muscle is a large, triangular and paired muscle located on the posterior aspect of the neck and thorax. 
  • Each trapezius muscle is flat and triangularly shaped, with the base of the triangle situated along the vertebral column (the muscle's origin) and the apex pointing toward the tip of the shoulder (the muscle's insertion).

 

 

  • Trapezius muscle shape:
    • Considering left or right side - triangular shape
    • Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trapezius muscle:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with gustatory sweating over the parotid region following parotidectomy done 6 months ago. Which nerve is most likely involved in this condition? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Auriculotemporal nerve

 

Explanation:

 

  • The auriculotemporal nerve is primarily involved in Frey's syndrome (gustatory sweating)
  • During parotidectomy, injury to this nerve can lead to misdirected regeneration of parasympathetic fibers
  • These fibers meant for salivary glands erroneously innervate sweat glands, causing sweating during eating

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Great auricular nerve:

 

  • While this nerve can be seen in the image and is commonly thickened in leprosy
  • It provides sensory innervation to the skin over parotid and external ear
  • It does not carry parasympathetic fibers that could cause gustatory sweating

 

Option B. Lesser occipital nerve:

 

  • Purely sensory nerve from C2
  • Supplies posterior scalp region
  • Not involved in autonomic innervation of parotid region

 

Option C. Facial nerve:

 

  • While it runs through parotid gland, it's primarily motor to facial muscles
  • Does not carry parasympathetic secretomotor fibers to sweat glands
  • Its injury causes facial paralysis, not gustatory sweating

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding nerve pathways in parotid region
  • Pathophysiology of Frey's syndrome
  • Role of different nerves in parotid region innervation
  • Post-surgical complications of parotidectomy
  • Clinical presentation and anatomical basis of auriculotemporal syndrome

questions.text: In the sagittal section of brain shown in the image, which structure serves as the target of fornix fibers (marked by arrow)? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Mammillary body

 

Explanation:

 

  • The fornix terminates in the mammillary bodies
  • These fibers form part of the Papez circuit
  • The hippocampo-mammillary tract via fornix is crucial for memory consolidation
  • Mammillary bodies receive these fibers in the post-commissural fornix

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hippocampus:

 

  • While the hippocampus is the origin of fornix fibers, not their target
  • The fornix carries efferent fibers from hippocampus to mammillary bodies
  • Forms critical part of limbic system for memory formation

 

Option B. Habenular nucleus:

 

  • Part of epithalamus
  • Connected via habenular commissure, not fornix
  • Involved in pineal regulation and reward processing

 

Option D. Amygdala:

 

  • Though part of limbic system
  • Not directly connected via fornix
  • Has separate pathways for emotional processing

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the Papez circuit components: 
    • Hippocampus → Fornix → Mammillary bodies → Mammillothalamic tract → Anterior thalamus → Cingulate cortex → Parahippocampal gyrus → Hippocampus
  • Clinical relevance: 
    • Korsakoff syndrome affects mammillary bodies
    • Memory disorders in fornix lesions
    • Role in episodic memory formation

questions.text: Which of the following is a function of the marked layer? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sodium and water retention

 

The image shows the adrenal gland, which is divided into the cortex and the medulla. The cortex is further subdivided into three layers: the zona glomerulosa, zona fasciculata, and zona reticularis.

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: This is the outermost layer of the adrenal cortex and is responsible for the production of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone. Aldosterone plays a key role in regulating sodium and water balance in the body, leading to sodium retention and water reabsorption in the kidneys.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gluconeogenesis: Gluconeogenesis is primarily a function of the zona fasciculata, which secretes glucocorticoids (e.g., cortisol) that promote glucose synthesis and metabolism.

 

Option C. Increased sex hormones: The zona reticularis is responsible for producing androgens, which are sex hormones. It does not contribute to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Immune cell interaction: While glucocorticoids from the zona fasciculata have some immunosuppressive effects, immune cell interaction is not a primary function of the marked layer, which is the zona glomerulosa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex is responsible for sodium and water retention through the secretion of mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone.

questions.text: Injury to which nerve results in absent gag reflex? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX & X

 

The gag reflex, also known as the pharyngeal reflex, is a protective mechanism that prevents foreign objects from entering the throat. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components:

 

  • Sensory Component (Afferent): The sensory part of the gag reflex is mediated by the Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX). When the posterior wall of the pharynx or the palate is touched, the sensory information is carried by the Glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla oblongata.
  • Motor Component (Efferent): The motor response, which causes the contraction of the pharyngeal muscles, is mediated by the Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X). This nerve provides the efferent pathway, leading to the muscle contraction observed in the gag reflex.

 

Injury to either of these nerves can disrupt the reflex: damage to CN IX affects the sensory input, while damage to CN X affects the motor response, resulting in an absent gag reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (VII & X): Cranial Nerve VII (Facial nerve) is not involved in the gag reflex. The Facial nerve primarily controls muscles of facial expression and does not play a role in the sensory or motor aspects of the gag reflex.

 

Option C (V & IX): Cranial Nerve V (Trigeminal nerve) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing, not for the gag reflex. Therefore, its involvement in the gag reflex is incorrect.

 

Option D (VII & IX): While Cranial Nerve IX is correctly identified as part of the reflex, Cranial Nerve VII is not involved. This makes the pairing incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gag reflex involves the Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for sensory input and the Vagus nerve (CN X) for motor response. Damage to either nerve can result in an absent gag reflex.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint marked in the image: (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Saddle

 

  • The marked joint in the image is the incudo-malleolar joint, which is a type of saddle joint. This joint is located in the middle ear and involves the malleus and incus bones. The mnemonic "SBI" helps remember the types of joints in relation to the incus:
    • S for Saddle joint (incudo-malleolar joint)
    • B for Ball and socket joint (incudo-stapedial joint)
    • I for the Incus, positioned in front and behind the respective joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ball and socket: Incorrect. The ball and socket joint is found in the incudo-stapedial joint, not the incudo-malleolar joint.

 

Option C. Plane: Incorrect. The plane joint is not represented in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Option D. Gliding: Incorrect. Gliding joints are not present in the middle ear ossicles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incudo-malleolar joint is a saddle joint, an important anatomical feature in the middle ear.

questions.text: The marked line corresponds to which vertebral level? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. L3

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a diagram with a line indicating the subcostal plane, which corresponds to a specific vertebral level. The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark and is used to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical purposes.

 

  1. Subcostal Plane: The subcostal plane passes through the lowest point of the costal margin, which is generally at the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).
  2. Anatomical Landmarks:
    • The subcostal plane is a horizontal plane that typically lies just below the rib cage.
    • It is an important reference point for dividing the abdomen into regions.
    • The umbilicus, lies at the level of the L3-L4 junction, but the subcostal plane is typically slightly superior to this and corresponds to L3.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T12: This is incorrect. T12 is located higher up in the thoracic region.

 

Option B. L1: This is incorrect. The transpyloric plane, passes through the level of L1.

 

Option C. L2: This is incorrect. L2 is also superior to the subcostal plane.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subcostal plane is an important anatomical landmark that typically corresponds to the level of the third lumbar vertebra (L3), helping to divide the abdomen into regions for clinical and surgical reference.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stomach

 

The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach.

 

 

The diagram shows the anterior relation of kidney:

 

 

The anterior relations of the left kidney involve various structures, including the stomach, spleen, and pancreas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spleen: The spleen is typically located more to the left side of the abdomen, and it is not a direct anterior relation of the left kidney. However, there may be some variability in the position of the spleen, and in some individuals, a small part of the spleen might be located anterior to the left kidney.

 

Option C. 2nd part of duodenum: The second part of the duodenum runs horizontally and is situated anterior to the right kidney, it has no relation to the left kidney. This part of the duodenum is part of the foregut and is involved in the digestion and absorption of nutrients.

 

Option D. Pancreas: Pancreas in general is related to the left kidney but below the level of relation with stomach. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stomach is located anterior to the left kidney. The part of the stomach that lies in close proximity to the left kidney is the lesser curvature, specifically the anterior aspect of the stomach. The left kidney is situated posterior to this portion of the stomach.

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.

questions.text: A patient presents with infection of the cavernous sinus with involvement of the nerve related on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral side

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (away from the midline, or towards the ear). The lateral rectus muscle’s action is essential for lateral gaze. If there is damage to the abducent nerve, the lateral rectus muscle will be paralyzed, leading to an inability to move the eye laterally and resulting in a medial squint (esotropia), where the eye turns inward.

 

To confirm involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards the lateral side. If the nerve is damaged, the patient will be unable to move the eye laterally, confirming the impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior side: Movement of the eye upward (superior gaze) is controlled primarily by the superior rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III). This is not the movement tested for the abducent nerve.

 

Option B. Inferior side: Inferior gaze (looking down) involves the inferior rectus and the superior oblique muscles, innervated by the oculomotor nerve and trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) respectively. This does not test the abducent nerve.

 

Option C. Medial side: Medial movement of the eye is controlled by the medial rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement is not used to assess the function of the abducent nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) controls the lateral rectus muscle, which moves the eye laterally. Damage to this nerve results in the inability to move the eye outward, leading to a medial squint (esotropia).

 

Mnemonic – EOM3 SO4 LR6 (all extraocular muscle are supplied by 3rd CN except Superior oblique which is supplied by 4th CN and lateral rectus muscle which is supplied by 6th cranial nerve)

questions.text: Which is not a branch of facial artery in the face?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mental

 

The first part of the maxillary artery gives rise to the mental artery as a terminal branch of the inferior alveolar artery.

 

The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery that runs a tortuous course through the submandibular region of the face, supplying blood to the muscles of facial expression, submandibular gland, and other structures in the face. The facial artery gives rise to several branches, including the superior and inferior labial arteries, which supply blood to the upper and lower lips, respectively. The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the lateral aspect of the nose.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Nasal: The lateral nasal artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies blood to the side of the nose.

 

Option C. Superior Labial: The superior labial artery is a branch of the facial artery that supplies the upper lip and surrounding areas.

 

Option D. Inferior Labial: The inferior labial artery is also a branch of the facial artery, and it supplies the lower lip and surrounding regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The mental artery is not a branch of the facial artery. Instead, it is a branch of the inferior alveolar artery, which is a branch of the maxillary artery. The mental artery supplies blood to the chin and lower lip.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles functions as a tensor of the vocal cords? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cricothyroid

 

Cricothyroid is a tensor of vocal cord.

 

The cricothyroid muscle is primarily responsible for lengthening and tensing the vocal cords. When this muscle contracts, it pulls the thyroid cartilage forward and down towards the cricoid cartilage, which results in elongation and tensioning of the vocal cords. This action increases the pitch of the voice. Because of its role in tensioning the vocal cords, the cricothyroid is sometimes referred to as a tensor of the vocal cords.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral cricoarytenoid: The lateral cricoarytenoid muscles are responsible for adducting the vocal cords. When these muscles contract, they rotate the arytenoid cartilages medially, which causes the vocal cords to come together. This action is crucial for phonation (production of sound), as the vocal cords must be close together to vibrate against each other. However, the lateral cricoarytenoids do not play a direct role in the tensioning or relaxation of the vocal cords.

 

Option C. Thyroarytenoids: The thyroarytenoids are the primary muscles within the vocal cords themselves. They have two parts: the thyrovocalis (medial) and the thyromuscularis (lateral). The thyrovocalis is involved in the shortening and tensioning of the vocal cords, leading to a decrease in pitch. In contrast, the thyromuscularis aids in relaxing and thickening the cords, which lowers the pitch. Together, they play a critical role in controlling pitch and the quality of the voice.

 

Option D. Posterior cricoarytenoids: The posterior cricoarytenoid muscles are the primary muscles responsible for abducting or opening the vocal cords. They rotate the arytenoid cartilages laterally, which pulls the vocal cords apart. This action is vital for breathing, as the vocal cords must be open for air to flow into the lungs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the corresponding region of the dura mater? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the incorrect pairing. The meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery doesn't primarily supply the dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa. The dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa is mainly supplied by branches from the vertebral arteries, such as the posterior meningeal artery.
  • The meningeal branches of Internal Carotid artery supply the anterior cranial fossa 
     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery. It is the most significant arterial supply to the dura mater. After entering the skull through the foramen spinosum, it typically divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies the dura mater overlying the anterior cranial fossa.

 

Option B. Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa: The accessory meningeal artery is a smaller branch that originates from the maxillary artery. It enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale. This artery supplies the dura of the middle cranial fossa.

 

Option D. Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries arise from the ophthalmic artery (a branch of the internal carotid artery). These arteries have meningeal branches that supply the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, specifically the region overlying the ethmoid bone and the frontal bone's adjacent parts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Summary of Blood supply to Dura

  1. Anterior cranial fossa
    1. By ethmoidal artery which is the branch of opthalmic artery which in tern is the branch of Internal carotid artery 
    2. Middle meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  2. Middle cranial fossa
    1. Accessory meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  3. Posterior Cranial fossa
    1. Meningeal branches from the branches of the vertebral artery.
       
  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) meningeal branch supply blood to the anterior cranial fossa.
  • The dura mater is supplied by meningeal arteries, which run along the inner periosteum (endosteum) of the skull and supply the following regions.

questions.text: Anterior fontanelle closes at which age? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 12-24 months

 

The anterior fontanelle is the largest of the fontanelles in an infant's skull, located at the junction of the frontal and parietal bones. It is diamond-shaped and is clinically significant as it remains open for a period after birth, allowing for the growth of the baby's brain and skull. The closure of the anterior fontanelle typically occurs between 12 to 24 months of age. This is an important developmental milestone and can vary slightly depending on individual growth patterns.

 

 

 

The provided images and discussion indicate that the anterior fontanelle is the last to close among the fontanelles. The posterior fontanelle closes around 3 months, the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle around 6 months, and the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelle around 12 months. Therefore, the anterior fontanelle, which closes between 12 to 24 months, is correctly identified by option A.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 0-3 months: Incorrect. The posterior fontanelle typically closes during this period.

 

Option C. 10-12 months: Incorrect. The fontanelles closing around this age are the posterolateral (mastoid) fontanelles.

 

Option D. 3-6 months: Incorrect. It corresponds to the closure time of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle, not the anterior fontanelle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The anterior fontanelle typically closes between 12 to 24 months of age, making this a key point for assessing normal infant development.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of woven (immature) bone? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Random collagen orientation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Woven bone has irregularly arranged collagen fibers
  • This random orientation is its defining characteristic
  • Results in lower mechanical strength compared to lamellar bone
  • Typically seen in embryonic development and fracture healing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bone marrow:

 

  • While present in bone cavities
  • Not specific to woven bone
  • Found in both mature and immature bone types
  • Primarily hematopoietic function

 

Option B. Haversian system:

 

  • Characteristic of mature lamellar bone
  • Absent in woven bone
  • Consists of organized concentric lamellae
  • Contains central canal with vessels

 

Option D. Trabeculae:

 

  • Feature of cancellous bone
  • Can be present in both woven and lamellar bone
  • Not specific to woven bone structure
  • Related to mechanical stress adaptation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding bone tissue types: 
    • Woven vs. Lamellar bone
    • Development sequence
    • Healing patterns
    • Clinical significance in: 
      • Fracture repair
      • Bone tumors
      • Developmental conditions
      • Metabolic bone diseases

questions.text: True regarding the lesion of the structure marked by 5 the arrow is: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wrist drop

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the radial nerve demonstrated in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the radial nerve leads to a wrist drop. Injury to the radial nerve leads to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. This results in an inability to extend the wrist and fingers actively, leading to the characteristic "wrist drop" appearance. The hand hangs flaccidly with the fingers flexed, and the person cannot extend them

 

 

Anterior view of the right cubital fossa:

 

The structures marked in the given image are:

 

  1. Branch of the median nerve to the brachialis muscle
  2. Biceps brachii muscle
  3. Brachialis muscle
  4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of fore arm
  5. Superficial branch of the radial nerve
  6. Brachioradialis muscle
  7. Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle
  8. Pronator teres muscle
  9. Brachial artery
  10. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm
  11. Median nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ape thumb deformity: This deformity is primarily associated with the median nerve lesion. It refers to an inability to oppose or flex the thumb due to weakness or paralysis of the thenar muscles (especially the opponens pollicis), which are innervated by the median nerve. This results in a flattened thenar eminence, giving the thumb an appearance reminiscent of an ape's thumb.

 

Option B. Claw hand: Claw hand, or "clawing" of the fingers, usually results from a combined ulnar and median nerve lesion. It is characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. It can also result from a high ulnar nerve lesion on its own. The claw hand deformity is not a typical consequence of radial nerve injury.

 

Option C. Claudication: Claudication refers to pain, cramping, or fatigue in muscles, typically the calves, during walking or exercise. It's a symptom of peripheral arterial disease, where there's reduced blood flow to the legs. This is not related to radial nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A child lacks thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Defective development of which of the following structures is likely to be the cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 3

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario presented here is suggestive of DiGeorge syndrome. This condition is caused by a defect in the development of the third pharyngeal pouch, denoted as 3.

 

DiGeorge syndrome, also known as 22q11.2 deletion syndrome, is a genetic disorder caused by a missing piece of chromosome 22. It is characterized by a wide range of symptoms that can vary in severity, but are typically grouped together using the mnemonic "CATCH-22":

 

C - Cardiac abnormalities, such as ventricular septal defects (VSD) and tetralogy of Fallot.

 

A - Abnormal facies, including a small chin, low-set ears, and wide-set eyes.

 

T - Thymic aplasia or hypoplasia, leading to a weakened immune system.

 

C - Cleft palate or other palate abnormalities.

 

H - Hypocalcemia or low levels of calcium due to underdeveloped or missing parathyroid glands.

 

22 - Refers to the chromosome 22q11.2 deletion, which causes the syndrome.

 

Other features that may be associated with DiGeorge syndrome include developmental delays, learning disabilities, behavioral problems, and psychiatric disorders. Treatment usually involves managing the individual symptoms and providing support to address any developmental or behavioral challenges

 

  • Cleft palate
  • Abnormal facies
  • Hypocalcemia, secondary to parathyroid aplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (1 - first pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, primarily associated with the development of structures like the middle ear and Eustachian tube.

 

Option B (2 - second pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, related to formations such as the palatine tonsils.

 

Option D (4 - fourth pharyngeal pouch): Incorrect, although related to the development of superior parathyroid glands, it is not primarily responsible for the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands like the third pouch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Derivatives of the Pharyngeal Pouches

 

 

The third pharyngeal pouch's proper development is crucial for the normal formation of the thymus and inferior parathyroid glands. Disruption in this development can lead to significant clinical symptoms like those seen in DiGeorge syndrome, emphasizing the need for genetic testing and comprehensive clinical management in affected individuals.

questions.text: The subclavian artery is divided into three parts by which of the following muscles? [Twisted PYQ]
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Scalenus anterior

 

Explanation:

 

  • The subclavian artery is divided into three parts by the scalenus anterior muscle
  • First part: From origin to medial border of scalenus anterior
  • Second part: Behind scalenus anterior
  • Third part: From lateral border of scalenus anterior to outer border of first rib

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pectoralis minor:

 

  • This muscle divides the axillary artery into three parts, not the subclavian artery
  • The parts are named in relation to pectoralis minor: above, behind, and below the muscle

 

Option C. Teres minor:

 

  • Rotator cuff muscle
  • Has no anatomical relationship with major blood vessels
  • Located in the posterior shoulder region

 

Option D. Teres major:

 

  • Forms the lower border where axillary artery becomes brachial artery
  • Does not divide any major artery into parts
  • Located in the posterior shoulder region

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understanding the anatomical relationships of subclavian and axillary arteries
  • Clinical importance of these relationships: 
    • Thoracic outlet syndrome
    • Surgical approaches to upper limb
    • Vascular access procedures
    • Compression syndromes
  • Knowledge of muscle relationships for identifying vessel segments in imaging and surgery

questions.text: The Para-sagittal section of the abdomen is given below. What is the superior border of the structure marked A?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caudate lobe of liver

 

Explanation:

 

Epiploic foramen is the structure indicated in the provided image. The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior boundary of the epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow.

 

Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac. The pearl summarizes the various relations of the foramen.

 

 

The caudate lobe is a small lobe of the liver situated on the posterior aspect, between the sulcus for the vena cava on the right and the fissure for the ligamentum venosum on the left. The caudate lobe forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duodenum: The duodenum is the first part of the small intestine immediately beyond the stomach. While the duodenum is closely related to the epiploic foramen, specifically the posterior surface of its first part, it does not form the superior border. Instead, it comprises the posterior boundary.

 

Option C. Lesser omentum: The lesser omentum is a double layer of peritoneum that extends from the liver to the lesser curvature of the stomach and the start of the duodenum. The free edge of the lesser omentum contains the bile duct, hepatic artery, and portal vein, forming the anterior border of the epiploic foramen.

 

Option D. Inferior vena cava: The inferior vena cava (IVC) is a large vein that carries deoxygenated blood from the lower and middle body into the right atrium of the heart. It is located posteriorly to the epiploic foramen but does not form the superior border. It creates the posterior boundary, similar to the duodenum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The epiploic foramen, also known as the foramen of Winslow, is a key anatomical passage within the abdominal cavity that connects the greater sac to the lesser sac.

 

The caudate lobe of the liver forms the superior border of this foramen.

questions.text: Identify the level of the cross-section shown in the image below. (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. T4-T5

 

Explanation:

 

The cross-section shown in the image is at the level of T4-T5.

 

Ascending and Descending aorta are visible separately along with bifurcation of pulmonary trunk, this implies it is the section of T4-T5 level.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:
