Options A, Option B: In cross-sections at the levels of T1-T2 and T2-T3, only the small vascular openings of the branches arising from the arch of aorta would be visible.

 

Option C: In cross section of T3-T4 level  - section of arch of aorta along with branches of arch of aorta would be visible

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bifurcation of pulmonary trunk along with separate ascending and descending aorta are clearing pointing towards T4-T5 level.

choices.text: Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid

questions.text: The correct pair of lymph node level in the neck and anatomical boundaries amongst the following are? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Level 6 - Hyoid to clavicle

 

Explanation:

 

The correct pair of lymph nodes and levels among the following options are level 6- Hyoid to clavicle.

 

Level 6 lymph nodes are the anterior or central compartment nodes. They span from the hyoid bone (superiorly) to the sternum/clavicle (inferiorly), and from the carotid arteries laterally. This group includes pretracheal, paratracheal, and precricoid (Delphian) nodes. These nodes often come into consideration in thyroid cancers and some laryngeal and hypopharyngeal malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Level 3 - Cricoid to clavicle: This is incorrect. Level 3 lymph nodes are located in the middle jugular region, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the hyoid bone (superiorly) and the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (inferiorly). They are situated along the middle third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option B. Level 4 - Hyoid to cricoid: This is also incorrect. Level 4 lymph nodes are the lower jugular nodes, and their anatomical boundaries are the lower border of the cricoid cartilage (superiorly) and the clavicle (inferiorly). These nodes are situated along the inferior third of the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

 

Option C. Level 5 - Base of skull to cricoid: This is not correct. Level 5 lymph nodes are located in the posterior triangle of the neck, which is bound by the sternocleidomastoid muscle (anteriorly), the trapezius muscle (posteriorly), and the clavicle (inferiorly). Level 5 is further divided into Level 5A (located above the cricoid) and Level 5B (located below the cricoid to the clavicle). So, Level 5 spans from the base of the skull to the clavicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lymph node level in the neck and their anatomical boundaries -

 

To aid in the description and localization of lymph nodes, especially in cancer treatment and surgery, they have been categorized into specific levels. Each level is defined by anatomical landmarks.

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the carotid sheath except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sympathetic chain

 

Explanation:

 

The carotid sheath's content is not the sympathetic chain. It is located in the neck, behind the carotid sheath and in front of the transverse processes of the cervical vertebrae.

 

The carotid sheath is a layer of loose connective tissue formed by adjacent portions of the investing layer of deep cervical fascia, the pretracheal fascia, and the prevertebral fascia.

 

Contents of carotid sheath:

 

  • Common and internal carotid arteries
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve (10th Cranial nerve)
  • Ansa cervicalis

 

Note: The glossopharyngeal, accessory, and hypoglossal nerves are located in the carotid sheath's upper portion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carotid artery: The common carotid artery and its internal branch (the internal carotid artery) are primary contents of the carotid sheath. In the neck, the common carotid bifurcates into the internal and external carotid arteries. Only the internal carotid artery continues to ascend within the carotid sheath.

 

Option C. Internal jugular vein: The internal jugular vein is a major vein in the neck that drains the brain, face, and much of the neck. It runs in close proximity to the internal and common carotid arteries and is another primary content of the carotid sheath.

 

Option D. 10th cranial nerve, which is also known as Vagus nerve. It is present in carotid sheath medial to internal jugular vein and lateral to internal carotid artery. It is a mixed nerve.It descends from the skull base through the jugular foramen and is present in the carotid sheath. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sympathetic chain (sympathetic trunk) is a bilateral series of ganglia that run vertically alongside the vertebral column. It is involved in the autonomic sympathetic innervation of the body. Importantly, the sympathetic chain itself is not contained within the carotid sheath. However, sympathetic fibers that come from the chain (e.g., the carotid plexus) do accompany structures within the sheath, especially the internal and common carotid arteries.

choices.text: Loss of sensation on forehead and dorsum of nose
Loss of sensation in jaw area
Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face
Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx

questions.text: What will be the clinical presentation if the nerve passing through the marked region has been injured? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of sensation on forehead and dorsum of nose

 

The marked region in the provided images corresponds to the superior orbital fissure, a key anatomical opening through which several cranial nerves pass. Among these, the frontal nerve, a branch of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, passes through this fissure. The frontal nerve further divides into the supratrochlear and supraorbital nerves, which supply sensation to the forehead and dorsum of the nose. Injury to this nerve results in loss of sensation in these areas.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Loss of sensation in jaw area: This area is primarily innervated by the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve, specifically the inferior alveolar, mental, and buccal nerves, which do not pass through the superior orbital fissure. Therefore, an injury to the nerve passing through the fissure would not affect sensation in the jaw area.

 

Option C. Loss of sensation in maxillary area of face: The maxillary area is innervated by the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve, which exits through the foramen rotundum, not the superior orbital fissure. Thus, injury at the superior orbital fissure would not impact this area.

 

Option D. Loss of sensation in the mucosa of nasopharynx: This region is primarily innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve and branches of the vagus nerve, which do not pass through the superior orbital fissure, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:


The superior orbital fissure allows the passage of nerves that supply sensation to the forehead and dorsum of the nose, including the frontal nerve, whose injury leads to sensory loss in these regions.

questions.text: Identify the histological structure shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pancreatic islet cells

 

  • The pancreas has two main parts: the exocrine and endocrine pancreas.
  • The endocrine part of the pancreas is composed of islets of Langerhans, which are characterized by secretory cells supported by reticulin fibers and numerous fenestrated capillaries.
  • Each islet is surrounded by a delicate capsule and appears paler than the surrounding exocrine cells due to the presence of less rough endoplasmic reticulum.
  • The image provided depicts the histology of the pancreas.

 

 

Pancreatic Islet Cells (Islets of Langerhans): Scattered throughout the pancreas, these islets are endocrine clusters differing from the surrounding exocrine pancreatic tissue.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Alpha Cells: Produce glucagon which increases blood glucose levels.
  • Beta Cells: The most common islet cell, producing insulin which decreases blood glucose levels.
  • Delta Cells: Produce somatostatin, which regulates the other islet cells.
  • Gamma Cells (PP or F cells): Produce pancreatic polypeptide, which regulates some of the pancreatic exocrine and endocrine functions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes are small, bean-shaped structures found throughout the lymphatic system.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: A dense connective tissue covering.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule that divide the node into compartments.
  • Cortex: Contains densely packed lymphocytes and has follicles with germinal centers.
  • Medulla: Central part containing medullary cords (lymphatic tissue) and medullary sinuses filled with lymph.
  • Hilum: The area where blood vessels and nerves enter and exit and where the efferent lymphatic vessels leave the node.

 

Option B. Glomerulus: A tuft of capillaries situated within Bowman's capsule in the nephron of the kidney.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Endothelial Cells: These line the inner surface of the capillaries.
  • Basement Membrane: Lies between the endothelial cells and the podocytes, playing a critical role in filtering the blood.
  • Podocytes: These are specialized epithelial cells that cover the outer surfaces of the glomerular capillaries. Their foot processes interdigitate and form filtration slits.
  • Mesangial Cells: Located between the capillary loops and provide structural support and phagocytic functions.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen is an intraperitoneal organ that filters blood and is involved in immune reactions.

 

Histological Features:

 

  • Capsule: Dense connective tissue with smooth muscle cells.
  • Trabeculae: Extensions from the capsule containing blood vessels.
  • White Pulp: Lymphatic tissue arranged around arterioles (central arteries). It's involved in immune responses.
  • Red Pulp: Consists of splenic cords (reticular connective tissue with many blood-filled sinuses). It filters the blood of antigens, microorganisms, and defective or worn-out red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which adult structure is derived from the embryological remnant marked as ‘A’ in the diagram? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median umbilical ligament

 

Marked structure A is the allantois, which forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.

 

The median umbilical ligament represents the remnant of the urachus (also known as the median umbilical fold). The urachus is a tubular structure that connects the fetal bladder to the umbilical cord and allows for the drainage of urine produced by the fetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid.

 

After birth, the urachus becomes non-functional and fibroses to form the median umbilical ligament. It extends from the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus within the median umbilical fold.

 

The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial umbilical ligament: These are the remnants of the occluded parts of the umbilical arteries. In fetal life, the umbilical arteries arise from the internal iliac arteries and pass to the umbilical cord, carrying deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

 

  • In the adult, they persist as the medial umbilical ligaments, which are paired fibrous bands on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall, running from the bladder to the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum arises from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct (or omphalomesenteric duct), which connects the yolk sac to the midgut lumen during embryonic development. It usually disappears by the 7th week of embryonic life.

 

  • If a portion of the vitelline duct remains, it can manifest as a Meckel's diverticulum. It's found in approximately 2% of the population and is often described by the "rule of 2s" - 2 inches long, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2% of the population, and can present with two types of epithelia (gastric and pancreatic).

 

Option D. Ligamentum teres (Round ligament of the liver):

 

  • The ligamentum teres represents the obliterated remnant of the left umbilical vein. During fetal development, the left umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta directly to the fetal heart, bypassing the liver through the ductus venosus.
  • After birth, the need for this shunt ceases, and the ductus venosus along with the left umbilical vein close up. The ligamentum teres runs in the free margin of the falciform ligament, connecting the umbilicus to the anterior aspect of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles form the pelvic diaphragm?

 

1. Iliococcygeus

2. Pubococcygeus

3. Obturator internus

4. Deep transverse perenei

(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1, 2

 

Explanation:

 

Iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus are parts of the pelvic diaphragm, which is also known as the levator ani. The pelvic diaphragm is a muscular partition that separates the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below. It consists of two paired muscles, the levator ani and the coccygeus (also known as the ischiococcygeus or the pubococcygeus), and their fascial coverings.

 

The levator ani muscle is a broad, thin muscle that forms the floor of the pelvic cavity. It consists of three parts: the pubococcygeus, the iliococcygeus, and the puborectalis.

 

  • Pubococcygeus muscle is the most medial of the three, and it arises from the pubic bone and the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle.
  • Iliococcygeus muscle arises from the fascia covering the obturator internus muscle and the ischial spine.
  • Puborectalis muscle is a sling-like muscle that forms a loop around the anorectal junction, and it arises from the pubic bone.

 

The coccygeus muscle is a small, triangular muscle that lies posterior to the levator ani muscle. It arises from the ischial spine and the sacrospinous ligament and inserts onto the coccyx.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. The obturator internus forms the lateral wall of the ischioanal fossa and is not a part of the levator ani.

 

Option D. The deep transverse perineal muscle is the content of the deep perineal space and contributes to the formation of the perineal body.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic diaphragm is formed by the iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus muscles, which are part of the levator ani muscle group. These muscles, including the puborectalis and coccygeus, contribute to the floor of the pelvic cavity and provide structural support, separating the pelvic cavity above from the perineum below.

questions.text: A patient underwent a coronary bypass graft with the great saphenous vein. The patient now complains of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be involved?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Saphenous nerve

 

  • The patient's symptoms of paresthesia and sensory loss over the medial aspect of the leg and foot indicate possible damage to the saphenous nerve, which can occur during a venous cutdown procedure to access the great saphenous vein for coronary bypass graft.
  • The saphenous nerve is a major cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve and is the longest nerve in the body.
  • After arising from the posterior division of the femoral nerve, it enters and exits the adductor canal before piercing the fascia lata between the gracilis and sartorius muscles.
  • From there, it runs along the medial border of the tibia alongside the great saphenous vein and supplies sensation to the skin over the patella, knee, leg, and foot, up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint.
  • During a venous cutdown procedure, injury to the saphenous nerve is common due to its proximity to the great saphenous vein.
  • The resulting sensory loss typically affects the medial aspect of the knee, leg, and foot.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial Peroneal Nerve: This nerve originates from the common peroneal nerve (a branch of the sciatic nerve). It runs in the lateral compartment of the leg.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies sensation to the dorsum (top) of the foot and a small area over the lateral aspect of the lower leg.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution and potential weakness in eversion of the foot.

 

Option C. Femoral Nerve: Arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L4).

 

  • Motor Functions: It supplies the anterior compartment muscles of the thigh which are primarily responsible for hip flexion and knee extension.
  • Sensory Distribution: Over the anterior thigh and medial aspect of the leg (via the saphenous nerve, its branch).
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Weakness in hip flexion and knee extension along with sensory loss over its distribution.

 

Option D. Sural Nerve: This nerve is formed by branches from both the tibial and common peroneal nerves. It runs along the posterior and then lateral side of the calf.

 

  • Sensory Distribution: Supplies the posterolateral aspect of the leg and the lateral side of the foot.
  • Clinical Manifestation of Injury: Loss of sensation in its sensory distribution.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine
A- Aldosterone, B- Androgen, C- Cortisol, D- Epinephrine
A- Aldosterone, B- Epinephrine, C- Androgen, D- Cortisol
A- Cortisol, B- Aldosterone, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

questions.text: Hormones secreted from A, B, C, D are respectively (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A- Aldosterone, B- Cortisol, C- Androgen, D- Epinephrine

 

The adrenal gland has distinct zones, each responsible for secreting specific hormones:

 

A. Zona Glomerulosa : Secretes mineralocorticoids, primarily aldosterone, which regulates blood pressure and electrolyte balance.

 

B. Zona Fasciculata : Secretes glucocorticoids, primarily cortisol, which regulates metabolism and immune response.

 

C. Zona Reticularis : Secretes androgens, which are precursors to sex hormones.

 

D. Adrenal Medulla : Secretes catecholamines, mainly epinephrine and norepinephrine, which are involved in the fight-or-flight response.

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The adrenal gland's zones and their respective hormones are:

 

  • Zona Glomerulosa: Aldosterone
  • Zona Fasciculata: Cortisol
  • Zona Reticularis: Androgens
  • Adrenal Medulla: Epinephrine

questions.text: Which of the following cranial nerve develops from second brachial arch? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Facial nerve

 

Branchial arches are also known as pharyngeal arches
 

The facial nerve is the nerve of the 2nd pharyngeal arch.

 

The facial nerve (seventh cranial nerve) is responsible for the motor innervation of the muscles of facial expression. Additionally, it provides taste sensation for the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and supplies parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular, sublingual, and lacrimal glands. The facial nerve is associated with the second brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve is the ninth cranial nerve (CN IX) arising from the medulla oblongata and is associated with the third brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It supplies sensation to the posterior third of the tongue, the upper pharynx, and the tonsil. It also has motor functions for the stylopharyngeus muscle and provides parasympathetic fibers to the parotid gland.

 

Option B. Trigeminal nerve: The trigeminal nerve is the fifth cranial nerve (CN V) and is primarily a sensory nerve for the face, with a smaller motor component for the muscles of mastication. The nerve develops in association with the first brachial (or pharyngeal) arch. It divides into three primary branches: the ophthalmic, maxillary, and mandibular nerves.

 

Option D. Vagal nerve: The vagus nerve is the tenth cranial nerve (CN X). It has a wide distribution and serves multiple functions in the body. Its functions include supplying motor innervation to the muscles of the pharynx and larynx, providing sensory information from the external ear and parts of the pharynx, and carrying parasympathetic fibers to thoracic and abdominal viscera. The vagus nerve is associated with the fourth (and a contribution from the sixth) brachial (or pharyngeal) arch.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The sensory area marked in the image is primarily innervated by which nerve? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Radial nerve 

 

The area marked in the image is supplied by radial nerve.

 

 

  • Origin: Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Primarily a motor nerve for the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm. It also has sensory branches for the skin on the back of the hand and the posterior arm and forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Triceps brachii, anconeus, brachioradialis, and all the extensor muscles in the forearm.
  • Sensory Innervation: Supplies the posterior surface of the arm and forearm, and the radial aspect of the dorsum of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN):

 

  • Origin: It's a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
  • Main Functions: Purely motor nerve that supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: All the deep extensors of the forearm, including extensor pollicis longus, extensor pollicis brevis, extensor indicis, and others.
  • Sensory Innervation: The PIN does not have a sensory function.

 

Option C. Median Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Formed by the union of the medial and lateral roots from the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies most of the flexor muscles in the forearm and some muscles in the hand.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor muscles in the anterior forearm (except flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus) and thenar muscles and first two lumbricals in the hand.
  • Sensory Innervation: Palmar aspect of the lateral three and a half fingers and the associated palm area.

 

Option D. Ulnar Nerve:

 

  • Origin: Arises from the medial cord of the brachial plexus.
  • Main Functions: Supplies muscles in the hand and a few in the forearm.
  • Motor Innervation: Flexor carpi ulnaris and the ulnar half of flexor digitorum profundus in the forearm. In the hand, it supplies most intrinsic muscles, including the hypothenar muscles, the palmar and dorsal interossei, and the third and fourth lumbricals.
  • Sensory Innervation: Provides sensation to the palmar and dorsal aspects of the medial one and a half fingers and the associated hand region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The sensory function of the radial nerve is provided by its four main sensory branches:

 

  • Inferior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies the lateral aspect of the anterior upper arm between the deltoid and the elbow.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Supplies part of the posterior aspect of the upper arm.
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the forearm: Supplies a tapered strip of the middle portion of the posterior forearm.
  • Superficial branch of the radial nerve: Supplies the posterior surface of the lateral 3 ½ digits and the associated areas of the palm.

questions.text: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distal end of ulna

 

Explanation:

 

The distal end of the ulna does not directly participate in the wrist joint. Instead, it articulates with the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC). The TFCC acts as a cushion and allows for the smooth rotation of the radius over the ulna during forearm pronation and supination. Due to this articulation with the TFCC and not with the carpal bones, the distal end of the ulna does not form the wrist joint.  .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scaphoid: The scaphoid is one of the eight carpal bones in the wrist and is situated on the radial side of the carpus. It articulates proximally with the radius and participates in the formation of the wrist joint.

 

Option B. Triquetrum: The triquetrum is another one of the carpal bones. It is located on the ulnar side of the carpus. Like the scaphoid, the triquetrum also articulates with the distal end of the radius, contributing to the wrist joint's structure.

 

Option C. Distal end of radius: The wrist joint is primarily formed by the articulation between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones, specifically the scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum. Thus, the distal end of the radius plays a crucial role in the formation and function of the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiocarpal joint, also known as the wrist joint, is a synovial, biaxial, and ellipsoid joint created by the articulation of:

 

  • Triangular fibrocartilage articular disc
  • The scaphoids, lunates, and triquetrum

 

Just the scaphoid and lunate are in contact with the radius and articular disc when the wrist is in its neutral position; the triquetrum does not come into contact with the disc until the wrist joint is fully adducted.

choices.text: Esophageal veins and left gastric veins
Left colic vein and middle colic veins

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with chronic liver disease presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension. Which of the following venous anastomoses is most likely responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

 

In the given scenario of a patient with portal hypertension, anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen.

 

In portal hypertension, increased pressure within the portal venous system may result in the dilation of portal venous tributaries and reversed flow at sites of portosystemic anastomoses.

 

The patient's presentation of abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension suggests an obstruction of the portal venous system, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses. These are communications between the portal venous system and systemic venous system, which allow blood from the abdominal organs to bypass the liver and flow directly into the systemic circulation.

 

The lower esophageal veins, which drain into the systemic circulation via the azygos system, can anastomose with the left gastric veins (which are part of the portal system). In the context of portal hypertension, such as from cirrhosis, the blood flow through this anastomosis increases, leading to the formation of esophageal varices. These are dilated veins in the esophagus and are at risk of rupture, which can result in significant and potentially fatal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left colic vein and middle colic veins:  Both these veins are tributaries of the inferior mesenteric vein and subsequently drain into the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: These veins aren't directly associated with the complications of portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Superior rectal and phrenic veins:  The superior rectal veins are branches of the inferior mesenteric vein and drain into the portal system, while the phrenic veins are systemic veins. However, these two veins do not directly anastomose.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not play a significant role in the portosystemic shunting seen in portal hypertension.

 

Option D. Sigmoid and superior rectal veins: The sigmoid veins and superior rectal veins both drain into the inferior mesenteric vein, which is a part of the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not contribute significantly to the clinical features of portal hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of Porto-systemic anastomoses and their clinical presentations are as follows:

choices.text: Anterior division of middle cerebral artery
Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery
Posterior division of middle cerebral artery

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Anterior division of the middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The area marked by an arrow in the given image is pterion and the artery that passes in close proximity to this area is the middle meningeal artery.

 

The middle meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery, enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum. Once inside, it divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery ascends vertically to supply the dura and the calvaria. Importantly, this artery courses in close proximity to the pterion. A blow to the pterion can fracture the thin bone here and rupture this artery, leading to an epidural hematoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

option A. Anterior division of middle cerebral artery: This artery is a branch of the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes of the brain. After the middle cerebral artery (MCA) exits the lateral sulcus, it bifurcates into its anterior and posterior divisions. However, the MCA and its divisions run deep within the brain, within the depths of the lateral sulcus and over the insular cortex. While they are critical for brain function, they don't have a direct relationship to the pterion on the external surface of the skull.

 

Option C. Posterior division of middle cerebral artery: Similar to the anterior division, the posterior division of the middle cerebral artery runs deep within the brain and does not have a direct relationship to the pterion.

 

Option D. Stem of middle meningeal artery: The stem of the middle meningeal artery is the segment between its origin (from the maxillary artery) and its bifurcation into anterior and posterior divisions. As it enters the cranium through the foramen spinosum, the stem is somewhat close to the pterion but it's the anterior division that actually courses near the pterion on the inner surface of the skull.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone

questions.text: Through which of the following marked sites does SARS-COVID 19 spread to the brain? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A

 

Explanation:

 

The structures marked in the given image are :

 

  1. Cribriform plate
  2. Foramen ovale
  3. Optic canal
  4. Foramen lacerum

 

The cribriform plate, marked as "A" in the image, is recognized as one of the potential entry routes for the SARS-CoV-2 virus to access the brain. The cribriform plate forms the roof of the nasal cavity and has small holes through which the olfactory nerves pass.

 

The virus can potentially enter the olfactory bulbs situated above the cribriform plate, which are directly connected to the nasal cavity. This provides a pathway for the virus to spread from the upper respiratory tract to the olfactory nerve endings (as well as dissemination through trans-synaptic transfer) and subsequently to the brain, potentially leading to neurological manifestations.

 

Encephalitis, demyelination, neuropathy, and stroke are the neurological sequelae to severe COVID-19 infection. The neurological invasion of the virus on the medullary cardiorespiratory center can lead to refractory respiratory failure in patients infected with COVID-19.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (D - Foramen Lacerum): Mainly filled with cartilage and does not transmit major nerves or blood vessels that could carry infections into the cranial cavity.

 

Option B (C - Optic Canal): Serves as the passage for the optic nerve from the eye to the brain, but not a known route for SARS-CoV-2 entry into the brain.

 

Option C (B - Foramen Ovale): A passage for the mandibular nerve, part of the trigeminal nerve, which has no established connection to SARS-CoV-2 neuroinvasion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cribriform plate is a plausible pathway for SARS-CoV-2 to access the brain due to its direct connection to the nasal cavity and olfactory system. Understanding these potential routes is crucial for comprehending the broader impact of the virus on the nervous system.

questions.text: Efferent to which nucleus of thalamus from indicated structure in the image? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

 

 

The image shows a coronal section of the brain with the indicated structure being the fornix. The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is involved in the Papez circuit, which plays a key role in the control of memory functions.

 

  • Anterior Nucleus of the Thalamus: The fornix carries signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is an integral part of the Papez circuit, involved in emotional and memory processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral: The lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in sensory relay and integration but are not the primary efferent targets of the fornix.

 

Option C. Ventro-postero-lateral: This nucleus is involved in the relay of sensory information from the body to the brain but is not connected to the fornix.

 

Option D. Pulvinar: The pulvinar nucleus is involved in visual processing and attention, not directly associated with the fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

choices.text: From the dorsal rami of C1

questions.text: Which nerve innervates the muscle marked in the given image? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dorsal scapular nerve

 

The above image shows the levator scapulae muscle, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve.

 

Dorsal scapular nerve arises from the brachial plexus, usually from the cervical nerve root C5. Muscles Supplied are Rhomboid major, Rhomboid minor and Levator scapulae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Suprascapular nerve: It is derived from the upper trunk of the brachial plexus, which is formed by the union of the C5 and C6 nerve roots. Muscles Supplied are Supraspinatus and Infraspinatus.

 

Option C. From the dorsal rami of C1: It is a spinal nerve root. Muscles Supplied are Suboccipital muscles (rectus capitis posterior major, rectus capitis posterior minor, obliquus capitis superior, and obliquus capitis inferior).

 

Option D. Subscapular nerve: It Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and contains fibers from C5 and C6. Muscles Supplied are Subscapularis and teres major muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appendicular group of back muscles and their innervations include: Superficial (appendicular) group of back muscles

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given structure: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. IV

 

Explanation:

 

In the given image, the dorsal aspect of the brainstem is marked and the cranial nerve that is passing there is the trochlear nerve (CN IV).

 

Trochlear nerve

 

  • Origin : The trochlear nerve is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal (posterior) aspect of the brain. Specifically, it originates from the dorsal surface of the midbrain, below the inferior colliculus.
  • Exit proceed to the superior orbital fissure to enter the orbit.
  • Function: It is a motor nerve that innervates a single extraocular muscle, the superior oblique muscle. The primary action of the superior oblique muscle is to intort (rotate inward), depress, and abduct the eyeball.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oculomotor Nerve (III):

 

  • Origin: The oculomotor nerve originates in the anterior aspect of the midbrain. Specifically, its fibers arise from the oculomotor nucleus, which is located in the superior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Exit Point: After emerging from the midbrain, it exits the brainstem at the level of the interpeduncular fossa (the space between the cerebral peduncles).
  • Function: It innervates most of the muscles controlling eye movements. It also contains parasympathetic fibers that are involved in pupil constriction and the lens's accommodation.

 

Option B. Facial Nerve (VII):

 

  • Origin: The facial nerve arises from the pons. Specifically, its fibers come from the facial nerve nucleus.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the brainstem at the cerebellopontine angle, between the pons and the medulla. It exits lateral to the abducens nerve and medial to the vestibulocochlear nerve (VIII).
  • Function: The facial nerve controls the muscles of facial expression. It also has taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and carries parasympathetic fibers to salivary and lacrimal glands.
     

Option D. Abducens Nerve (VI):

 

  • Origin: The abducens nerve originates in the pons. Its fibers arise from the abducens nucleus, which is located in the dorsal pons near the floor of the fourth ventricle.
  • Exit Point: It emerges from the ventral surface of the brainstem at the junction between the pons and the medulla, in the groove between the pons and the pyramid of the medulla.
  • Function: It innervates the lateral rectus muscle, which abducts the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve is the fourth cranial nerve that originates in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus from the trochlear nuclei. It is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the brainstem's dorsal surface and has the longest intracranial course.

 

The main actions of superior oblique are:

 

  • Depression in adducted position- Patients with trochlear nerve palsy have difficulty in looking downwards when eyes are in the adducted position.
  • Abduction
  • Intorsion of the eyeball.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the picture given below? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked "A" is the levator ani muscle which is part of the pelvic diaphragm.

 

The levator ani is the principal muscle of the pelvic floor and is composed of three parts: the puborectalis, the pubococcygeus, and the iliococcygeus. It is primarily innervated by the pudendal nerve and the S4 nerve root.

 

 

 

The structure marked in the given image are:

 

A. Levator ani

B. Sphincter ani externus

C. Obturator muscle

D. Perianal fascia

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sphincter Ani Externus (External Anal Sphincter): This is a circular muscle that surrounds the anus. It's located below the level of the levator ani. It is innervated by the pudendal nerve, allowing for voluntary control over defecation.

 

Option C. Obturator Muscle: This term often refers to two muscles - obturator externus and obturator internus. They are situated on either side of the obturator membrane in the pelvis. Obturator Externus: Obturator nerve and Obturator Internus: Nerve to obturator internus (a branch of the sacral plexus).

 

Option D. Perianal Fascia: The perianal fascia is not a muscle but is the connective tissue located in the perianal region, around the anus. It's part of the deeper layers of the skin in this region.  It's associated with various potential spaces that can become sites of abscess formation if there's an infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The levator ani muscle is a key component of the pelvic diaphragm, supporting pelvic organs and aiding in fecal continence, illustrating its critical role in both pelvic structure and function.

questions.text: Meissner corpuscles are present in: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Papillary dermis

 

Explanation:

 

The papillary dermis is the uppermost layer of the dermis, lying directly beneath the epidermis. It is named so because of its projections called dermal papillae that interlock with the rete ridges of the epidermis.

 

These dermal papillae increase the surface area between the epidermis and dermis, allowing for better nutrient exchange and anchoring. Meissner corpuscles, also known as tactile corpuscles, are located in the papillary dermis, especially in areas sensitive to light touch, such as the fingertips and lips. They are oval-shaped mechanoreceptors that are sensitive to fine touch and low-frequency vibration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is the deeper and thicker layer of the dermis, located beneath the papillary dermis. It comprises mainly of dense irregular connective tissue containing collagen and elastin fibers. While it contains other structures like sweat glands, hair follicles, and blood vessels, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.

 

Option C. Basal epidermis: The basal epidermis, or stratum basale, is the innermost layer of the epidermis. It consists of a single layer of columnar or cuboidal keratinocytes. These cells are continuously dividing and pushing older cells upwards towards the skin surface. The basal layer also contains melanocytes, which produce the pigment melanin, and Merkel cells, another type of tactile mechanoreceptor. However, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.

 

Option D. Stratum lucidum: The stratum lucidum is a thin, clear layer of the epidermis, typically found only in areas of thick skin such as the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It lies between the stratum corneum (outermost layer) and the stratum granulosum. The stratum lucidum is made up of dead, flat keratinocytes that have a translucent appearance. Meissner corpuscles are not located in this epidermal layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Melanocyte are found in Stratum basale
  • Merkel cell found in stratum basale
  • Meissner corpuscles found in papillary dermis
  • Keratohyaline granules are found in stratum granulosum
  • Keratin is found in Stratum corneum & lucidum
     

 

Meissner corpuscles are found in papillary dermis, are enriched in the fingers and toes, and have an unmyelinated nerve terminal that is surrounded by Schwann cells.
